Award.AwardTitle: Planning Visit: Thin Film/Cellulose Integrated Circuitry International Collaboration between University of Texas at Dallas and the New University of Lisbon
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the establishment of a new international research collaboration between the University of Texas-Dallas (UTD) and the New University of Lisbon (UNL) in Portugal. Researchers at UNL focus on materials research, and recently demonstrated the use of cellulose based paper as either a substrate for physical support of electronic devices (such as organic thin film transistors, logic circuits and electrochromic displays) or as an ?interstrate? structure where the device is built on both sides of the cellulose sheet. The group at UT Dallas focuses on device design and process integration, and recently demonstrated Flexible CMOS digital gates and integrated column drivers for electrophoretic displays, non-volatile memory based on the organic ferroelectric polymer P(VDF-TrFE), and flexible displays based on organic thin-film transistors and organic light emitting diodes. In the current catalytic project, the two teams will work together to develop new devices based on integrating novel device structures and circuits on cellulose substrates, providing the possibility for very inexpensive, highly functional electronic paper.

The broader impacts of the planning visit supported through this award are substantial. The development of a new field of electronics based upon cellulose is potentially transformative, and the complementary research expertise and infrastructure will foster strong international collaborations. Student researchers will participate in the planning visit to Portugal and gain valuable international experience and networks. Anticipated follow-on activities also include the development of long-term exchange programs for both US and Portuguese students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the  proposed planning visit was to develop both research and educational programs between the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) in Dallas, TX and the New University of Lisbon (UNL) in Lisbon, Portugal. This emergent relationship was built upon preliminary meetings sponsored by the Texas-Portugal University Enterprise Network.  From initial discussions centered on specific research topics related to thin films and advanced circuitry substrates, the universities were found to be very complementary in facilities, research areas and academic units. Additionally, both universities have been tasked with expanding international collaborations to raise the quality and expand the scope of student education as well as enhance the research programs and international reputation of each university.  Our plan to develop this collaboration is holistic and builds on the concept of simultaneously developing both academic and research relationships to ensure the long-term success of the overall collaboration. Thus, the proposed planning visit includes development on both the academic and research fronts. Academic and Research collaboration at the University of Texas at Dallas is spearheaded by their VP of Research Dr. Bruce Gnade, Dr. Manuel Quevedo and Dr. Walter Voit, all from the Materials Science and Engineering Dept. at UT Dallas.  Dr. Martins and Dr. Fortunato from Materials Science at the New University of Lisbon will be actively involved in the planning visit.

We were not able to have the planning visit to the University of New Lisbon due to scheduling difficulties, so there is nothing to report.
